title: High-resolution Holocene South American monsoon history recorded by a speleothem from Botuverá Cave, Brazil
abstract: Abstract A Holocene stalagmite from Botuvera Cave, southeastern Brazil was analyzed by LA-ICPMS for Mg/Ca, Sr/Ca, Ba/Ca. The observed variability in the record was demonstrated to be modulated by prior calcite precipitation, and, thus, is interpreted to reflect monsoon intensity. We find that the calcite δ18O is strongly correlated with Sr/Ca, indicating that atmospheric circulation over South America and monsoon intensity have been tightly correlated throughout most of the Holocene, both directly responding to solar precession. Comparison with other contemporaneous high-resolution hydroclimate records reveals that SAMS has shown a degree of complexity during the Holocene not previously detected, with periods where the South American Convergence Zone (SACZ) expanded to cover most of the South American sub-continent, and coincident with periods of low-SST in the north Atlantic. We also detect periods where rainfall amount in northeastern and southeastern Brazil are markedly anti-phased, suggesting a north-south migration of SACZ, which it appears to be mediated by solar irradiance. The high-resolution nature of our record allow us to examine the effect that Holocene climate anomalies had upon SAMS dynamics and hydroclimate in southeastern Brazil, in particular the 8.2 ka event and the Little Ice Age. In addition to confirm the internal structure of the events, we also detect the possible consequences of the climatic anomalies upon ocean–atmosphere interactions through its effects upon SAMS.

motivations: There is a need to better understand the Holocene history of the South American monsoon system (SAMS) and its dynamics.
The complexity of SAMS during the Holocene is not well understood, and high-resolution records are required to elucidate its variability and response to climate anomalies.
objectives: Reconstruct a high-resolution Holocene history of SAMS using a speleothem from Botuverá Cave, Brazil.
Investigate the relationship between SAMS intensity and atmospheric circulation over South America.
Examine the impact of Holocene climate anomalies on SAMS dynamics and hydroclimate in southeastern Brazil.
methods: Analyze a stalagmite from Botuverá Cave using LA-ICPMS for Mg/Ca, Sr/Ca, Ba/Ca, and calcite δ18O.
Compare the obtained record with other contemporaneous high-resolution hydroclimate records.
Examine the correlation between SAMS intensity and solar precession, as well as the relationship between SAMS and ocean–atmosphere interactions.
results: Provide a high-resolution record of SAMS history during the Holocene, revealing previously undetected complexity.
Demonstrate the tight correlation between SAMS intensity and atmospheric circulation over South America, both responding to solar precession.
Elucidate the impact of Holocene climate anomalies, such as the 8.2 ka event and the Little Ice Age, on SAMS dynamics and hydroclimate in southeastern Brazil.

motivations: Understanding the complexity and dynamics of the South American Monsoon System (SAMS) during the Holocene requires high-resolution paleoclimate records.
Previous studies have not fully captured the spatial and temporal variability of monsoon intensity and atmospheric circulation patterns over South America.
objectives: Reconstruct high-resolution Holocene monsoon history and atmospheric circulation patterns over South America using speleothem geochemical proxies.
Examine the effects of major climate anomalies on SAMS dynamics and southeastern Brazil hydroclimate.
methods: Analyzed stalagmite samples from Botuverá Cave using LA-ICPMS to measure Mg/Ca, Sr/Ca, and Ba/Ca ratios as proxies for prior calcite precipitation and monsoon intensity.
Compared speleothem records with other contemporaneous high-resolution hydroclimate records to assess regional climate patterns.
Examined correlations between calcite δ18O and trace element ratios to understand atmospheric circulation and monsoon dynamics.
results: Revealed that SAMS exhibited greater complexity during the Holocene than previously detected, including periods of South American Convergence Zone expansion and north-south migration.
Demonstrated tight correlation between atmospheric circulation and monsoon intensity throughout the Holocene, both responding to solar precession.
Identified anti-phased rainfall patterns between northeastern and southeastern Brazil, suggesting SACZ migration mediated by solar irradiance.
